page.title: Welcome to Unit 1
page.contents:
Increasing the Rigor of Adult English Language Acquisition* Instruction

Using the buttons at the bottom will present the materials in order. You can also navigate to the pages in this section by using the Lesson menu on the left.

*The Workforce Innovation and Opportunities Act uses the term English language acquisition (ELA) to describe English language instruction for nonnative English speakers rather than the traditional English as a second language (ESL) or English for speakers of other languages terminology.

page.title: Objectives for Instructors
page.contents:
By the end of this unit, you should be able to do the following:

  • Articulate why we need to increase the rigor of adult ELA instruction.
  • Define and give examples of academic language, listening and reading strategies, and critical thinking skills.
  • Identify the complex language needs for various learner profiles.

page.title: Objectives for Administrators
page.contents:
By the end of this unit, you should be able to do the following:

  • Articulate why we need to increase the rigor of adult ELA instruction.
  • Identify the complex language needs for various learner profiles.
  • Describe legislation and trends that support the need for increased rigor in instruction for all adult ELLs.

page.contents:

Note for Administrators: Even if you are not completing tasks for teachers in Parts 1 and 2, consider working through Parts 1 and 2 for background on what academic language entails for learners and instructors.

page.title: Reflecting on Your Successes as a Professional
page.contents:
You employ a variety of skills and strategies that contribute to success in your personal and professional life. Complete this Inventory of Personal Skills and reflect on the questions below:

After completing the survey of skills, consider…

  1. When do you use these skills in your personal and professional life?
  2. How did you acquire these skills?
  3. Which skills do you find adult ESL learners use most readily?
  4. Which of these seem most difficult for adult ESL learners you serve?

Click on the audio to hear an explanation of why we need to embed these kinds of skills at all levels of instruction in adult ESL from the beginning.

ELL_Mod1_0010.mp3

Also view Inventory of Personal Skills and Strategies for Success 

Audio transcript


No doubt you discovered that you use the skills and strategies in this inventory often without really thinking about it. The skills included in this inventory can fall into different categories. There is academic language, for example, adapting language to a variety of contexts and communicative tasks. You know that you need to address an officer of the law differently than you might a family member. You know that an email to your spouse will be written very differently than a letter to a teacher at school.

You use language strategies, for example, you read texts differently depending on your purpose; you probably scan the weather page for the high and low to decide how to dress in the morning. When you get to work, you might read an email from your boss about an upcoming structural change in the school very carefully.

You employ critical thinking skills, for example, you synthesize information from multiple sources. When you need to do a presentation or write something for school or work, you don’t gather information from only one source, do you? When you are making a major purchase, you may do the same thing. Then you analyze, compare, and contrast the information.

Finally, the inventory included essential skills such as note-taking, planning, and organizing strategies.

You may have acquired these skills through models from parents, friends, teachers, or co-workers. You may have had explicit instruction in some of these in a study skills class at school, for example, note-taking strategies. You have been in school settings that put a high premium on writing for different purposes and on critical thinking. Whether your adult English language learners readily employ these skills may be largely dependent on their educational backgrounds. We know that acquisition of these academic skills is dependent on experience with formal schooling and those learners with limited formal schooling may take more than ten years of instruction to acquire them. Adult English language learners may have limited opportunities to develop skills like these outside of classes. This is why we need to include them early and often.

Why are they so important? As we will explore in this unit, we live in a changing economic and work landscape. The nature of jobs has changed over the past century. According to the 2007 State New Economy Index, “Workers who were skilled with their hands and could reliably work in repetitive and sometimes physically demanding jobs were the engine of the old economy. In today’s New Economy, knowledge-based jobs are driving prosperity… positions held by individuals with at least two years of college.” New jobs require extensive use of both oral and written language; they involve working with complex texts; they involve more interactions with co-workers. Incorporating instruction in the types of skills and strategies in the inventory will not only help adult English language learners prepare for those jobs, but also help them to be more engaged language learners and community members. Building academic language, language skills and strategies, and critical thinking means increased rigor in English language instruction.

page.title: The Language Demands of Work
page.contents:
To be successful at work, learners need to…

  • read charts, forms, or work instructions.
  • interact effectively with co-workers on teams (e.g. ask for clarification, ask others’ opinions).

Listen to audio:
ELL_Mod1_0020.mp3 

Audio transcript


Development of academic language, language strategies, critical thinking, and organizing and note-taking skills will allow students to thrive in all areas of life. At work, adults may need to read charts, forms, and work instructions, which all require the use of different reading strategies. They need language for interacting effectively with co-workers on teams (for example, asking for clarification, or asking others’ opinions).

page.title: Language Demands in Post-secondary Education
page.contents:
To succeed in any training, learners need to…

  • do extensive note-taking.
  • ask clarifying questions.
  • employ multiple reading strategies.
  • read complex non-fiction texts.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod1_0030.mp3 

Audio transcript


In this module, we are not referring to postsecondary education only as completion of a two- or four-year degree. We are referring to any training beyond high school, as well as work-based certifications or training. To succeed in any postsecondary setting or work-related training, students need to do extensive note-taking, ask clarifying questions, and employ multiple reading strategies. They will need to read and comprehend complex non-fiction texts and write reports or research papers. Adult English language learners can be ill-prepared for this kind of reading and writing due to the fact that in basic literacy curricula, we often focus on short, personal narratives for reading and writing.

page.title: Language Demands at Home and in the Community
page.contents:
To thrive at home and in the community, learners need to…

  • read mail selectively.
  • listen and take phone messages.
  • assist their children with homework.
  • interact with teachers at school conferences.
  • attend neighborhood meetings.
  • make decisions about services, for example health care.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod1_0040.mp3 

Audio transcript


These skills are not only for work or school readiness, however. At home, adults need to read mail selectively, listen and take notes if they receive important phone messages, or assist their children with homework. To be involved in the community, they may want to attend neighborhood meetings, interact with teachers at school conferences, all of which may require using higher order listening and communication skills in English. They need to make decisions about services in their communities, for example health care, which require print and digital literacy as well as critical thinking skills.

page.title: Think about Aadan's Needs
page.contents:
Now you will meet Aadan and learn about some of his specific circumstances and needs.

Listen to audio

Meet Aadan from Somalia

ELL_Mod1_0050.mp3

Audio transcript


Aadan came to the United States nine years ago as a refugee when he was 19. Before that, he attended school for only three years in a refugee camp and has minimal literacy skills in his own language. He is married and has four school-aged children. He works as an attendant in a parking garage and attends ELA classes three mornings a week. Due to his limited literacy skills, he has been placed in a beginning-level ELA class. At the same time, he has strong oral skills and is quite confident communicating with teachers and people in his community. His dream is to one day get a high school equivalency.

Think about Aadan’s needs: Consider these questions about Aadan’s goals, background, strengths and needs. 

1. What can we infer about about Aadan’s personal and professional goals based on the information provided?

2. What complex language and skills are required if Aadan one day wants to achieve his goal of getting a high school equivalency diploma?

3. What are Aadan's strengths? What challenges might he face? What are some ways you can build on his strengths and help him overcome his challenges?

4. In what ways is Aadan representative of students you serve in your classes or program?

Now go to An Analysis of Aadan’s Needs and compare it to your own answers on the reflection task.

Listen to Audio:
A note on your reflection of Aadan's needs

ELL_Mod1_0060.mp3

Audio transcript


If you are working through this unit with a colleague, think about all of the academic language and critical thinking skills you used when analyzing Aadan’s situation. You needed to read between the lines and make some inferences about his goals and aspirations based on the information provided. In discussing this vignette with a colleague, you no doubt used a lot of rich academic language, for example:

“I think we can infer that Aadan lacks foundational academic skills because of his limited formal schooling.”

That’s exactly the kind of language adult English language learners need to acquire, so we will be calling attention to those moments in this module when you use complex language and skills.

Now that you have reflected on the kinds of skills and strategies you use in your daily life and learned how a student like Aadan needs to acquire those same kinds of skills and strategies, it’s time to move to formal definitions and further examples of academic language, reading and listening strategies, and critical thinking.

page.title: Three Key Areas
page.contents:
Considering the academic, career and personal needs of adult ESL learners in today’s world, there are three key areas that we can be intentional about integrating into instruction: Academic language, language strategies, and critical thinking. In doing so, we are providing adult ESL learners with skills for success at school, work, at home and in their communities. We are making instruction more rigorous. What does each of those areas mean exactly?

Academic Language Language Strategies Critical Thinking

You will be presented with information about all three of these topics and will be able to check your understanding.

page.title: Why is increased rigor so important?
page.contents:
Take a few minutes to think about the language skills your learners need for success in these contexts. Consider your ideas and then move through the next three pages to compare your ideas.

The language and skills needed for success in most workplaces

The language and skills needed for success in further education

The language and skills needed for full access to opportunities at home and in communities

page.title: Academic Language
page.contents:
Academic language is defined as “… the set of words, grammar, and discourse strategies used to describe complex ideas, higher order thinking processes, and abstract concepts” (Zwiers, 2014, p. 22). Much of what is written on academic language development is in the world of k-12 education. It is considered the language of school, allowing ELLs to access and develop content knowledge along with their mainstream peers. What role does this play in adult ESL? A big one! Academic language should be defined in this context as both academic and professional language; it is language that can be used in work, community and school interactions.

Much of what we teach in adult ESL classes is “social” English. In a typical adult ESL class, we often put more emphasis on basic communication skills in everyday situations than on interacting for academic or professional purposes. In those every-day settings, it's possible to communicate imprecisely or use casual language. A speaker or listener can repair misunderstandings by pointing to something to show what they mean. These are great communication strategies (and don’t stop teaching them)! Will a student get by with informal, social language in a job interview, or when writing a report at work? There is a layer of “academic language” that we can start teaching early.

 According to Robin Scarcella, “Learning academic English is probably one of the surest, most reliable ways of attaining socioeconomic success in the United States today. This variety of English entails the multiple, complex features of English required for long-term success in public schools, completion of higher education, and employment with opportunity for professional advancement and rewards.” Scarcella, R. (2003)

page.title: Language Strategies
page.contents:
Connected to academic language are the actual strategies we employ actively while reading complex texts or listening to extended speech (directions from a boss, a presentation at a child's school, a lecture). We know from the research that skilled readers make use of a variety of strategies, some bottom-up (e.g. decoding words) and many top-down (e.g. using visual cues to aid in comprehension; drawing on prior knowledge). Similarly, skilled listeners listen selectively for particular words or phrases; they monitor their comprehension; and they use clues to infer the meaning of unknown words. These reading and listening strategies should be introduced and practiced long before learners reach advanced levels.

Typical adult ESL curricula do include reading and listening activities. We want to make sure that we pay attention to using more non-fiction texts, longer authentic listening passages, and that we explicitly teach and name strategies that learners can employ on their own outside of our classrooms. Of course there are reading, listening, writing and speaking skills. We will focus on reading and listening to understand complex language in this unit.

 There is research that indicates that the complexity of text a learner can read is the greatest predictor of success in college and careers (Pimentel, 2013).

page.title: Critical Thinking Skills
page.contents:
Critical thinking is the process of questioning and reflection that allows us to understand, evaluate, and solve problems and take informed action. Critical thinking skills are vital for adults to thrive in their communities, in postsecondary education, and at work. Adult ESL learners have plenty of practice with critical thinking skills; most have made complex decisions for themselves and their families about their lives in the United States, their jobs, and their children’s schooling. They need the language of and practice with critical thinking in new contexts. For example, when questioning an assumption in English, we use phrases like these:

  • That’s true, but I wonder about…
  • Why do you think that is?

To synthesize ideas, we might say:

  • It seems from our discussion that…
  • The main points seem to be…

We need to teach learners this language and give them practice with it so that they can put their ideas into words.

Check your understanding of the components of rigorous language with the next task.

It is a misconception that adults in ESL classes do not know how to think critically or employ higher order thinking skills. Most adult ESL students have made complex decisions for themselves and their families about their lives in the United States, their jobs, and their children’s schooling, and many speak two or more languages. At the same time, they may have had limited experience with formal schooling or have come from an educational system that does not focus on critical thinking or development of higher order thinking skills.

(Parrish and Johnson, 2010)

page.title: Analyzing Inez's Needs
page.contents:
Applying What you have Learned

Now you will get practice analyzing two more learners, Inez from Ecuador and Carlos from Mexico. This time, draw on examples of academic language, language strategies, and critical thinking that have been presented. Compare their needs to Aadan’s and to learners in your own classes or program.

Meet Inez from Ecuador

Listen to audio

ELL_Mod1_0070.mp3 

Audio transcript


Inez has 3 school-aged children. She works in housekeeping at a hotel and is enrolled in a low-intermediate-level ESL class at a volunteer-run program in her community. The program she attends has a largely life-skills curriculum. Inez feels frustrated because people don’t understand her. She has a hard time explaining problems because she can’t express herself well in English. She has trouble communicating with her boss. Her dream is to get a high school equivalency diploma and then to become a nurse.

What are Inez’s’s goals and what do you think she’ll need in her English class to get there? Go to the reflective task Analyzing Inez’s Needs now.

Analyzing Inez’s Needs: Answer these questions about Inez’s goals, background, strengths and needs. Discuss your answers if you are working with other teachers.

1. What can we infer about about Inez’s personal and professional goals based on the information provided?

2.  What complex language and skills are required if Inez one day wants to achieve her goal of getting a high school equivalency diploma?

3 What are Inez's strengths?  What challenges might she face? What are some ways you can build on her strengths and help her overcome his challenges?

4. In what ways is Inez representative of students you serve in your classes or program?

page.title: Analyzing Carlos's Needs
page.contents:
Meet Carlos from Mexico

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod1_0080.mp3

Audio transcript


Carlos was a high school math teacher in his country. Currently, he works in a manufacturing company as he improves his English. Carlos needs to work with his state to see if he meets licensure requirements. He most certainly needs to take some education classes and pass state teacher exams, but he feels like that is a long way off. Right now, he is in an high-intermediate-level ELA class in a large, urban adult education program. He hasn’t scored high enough to be placed in the more advanced college bridge courses, but he thinks that’s what he needs to get ahead.

What are Carlos’s goals and what do you think he’ll need in his ESL class to get there? 

Analyzing Carlos’s Needs: Answer these questions about Carlos’s goals, background, strengths and needs. Discuss your answers if you are working with other teachers.

1. What can we infer about about Carlos’s personal and professional goals based on the information provided?

2. What complex language and skills are required if Carlos one day wants to achieve his goal of  becoming a math teacher in the United States?

3. What are Carlos's strengths? What challenges might he face? What are some ways you can build on his strengths and help him overcome his challenges?

4. In what ways is Carlos representative of students you serve in your classes or program?

page.title: What do Inez and Carlos need?
page.contents:
Now click on each image for a full analysis of each vignette and compare what is presented to your own analysis of each.

Inez

Carlos

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
